14#ifndef ISC_SOCKET_H
15#define ISC_SOCKET_H 1
16
17/*****
18 ***** Module Info
19 *****/
20
21/*! \file isc/socket.h
22 * \brief Provides TCP and UDP sockets for network I/O. The sockets are event
23 * sources in the task system.
24 *
25 * When I/O completes, a completion event for the socket is posted to the
26 * event queue of the task which requested the I/O.
27 *
28 * \li MP:
29 * The module ensures appropriate synchronization of data structures it
30 * creates and manipulates.
31 * Clients of this module must not be holding a socket's task's lock when
32 * making a call that affects that socket. Failure to follow this rule
33 * can result in deadlock.
34 * The caller must ensure that isc_socketmgr_destroy() is called only
35 * once for a given manager.
36 *
37 * \li Reliability:
38 * No anticipated impact.
39 *
40 * \li Resources:
41 * TBS
42 *
43 * \li Security:
44 * No anticipated impact.
45 *
46 * \li Standards:
47 * None.
48 */
49
50/***
51 *** Imports
52 ***/
53
54#include <inttypes.h>
55#include <stdbool.h>
56
57#include <isc/event.h>
58#include <isc/eventclass.h>
59#include <isc/lang.h>
60#include <isc/json.h>
61#include <isc/region.h>
62#include <isc/sockaddr.h>
63#include <isc/time.h>
64#include <isc/types.h>
65#include <isc/xml.h>
66
67ISC_LANG_BEGINDECLS
68
69/***
70 *** Constants
71 ***/
72
73/*%
74 * Maximum number of buffers in a scatter/gather read/write. The operating
75 * system in use must support at least this number (plus one on some.)
76 */
77#define ISC_SOCKET_MAXSCATTERGATHER 8
78
79/*@{*/
80/*!
81 * Socket options:
82 *
83 * _REUSEADDRESS: Set SO_REUSEADDR prior to calling bind(),
84 * if a non-zero port is specified (applies to
85 * AF_INET and AF_INET6).
86 */
87typedef enum {
88 ISC_SOCKET_REUSEADDRESS = 0x01U,
89} isc_socket_options_t;
90/*@}*/
91
92/*%
93 * Statistics counters. Used as isc_statscounter_t values.
94 */
95enum {
96 isc_sockstatscounter_udp4open = 0,
97 isc_sockstatscounter_udp6open = 1,
98 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp4open = 2,
99 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp6open = 3,
100 isc_sockstatscounter_unixopen = 4,
101
102 isc_sockstatscounter_udp4openfail = 5,
103 isc_sockstatscounter_udp6openfail = 6,
104 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp4openfail = 7,
105 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp6openfail = 8,
106 isc_sockstatscounter_unixopenfail = 9,
107
108 isc_sockstatscounter_udp4close = 10,
109 isc_sockstatscounter_udp6close = 11,
110 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp4close = 12,
111 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp6close = 13,
112 isc_sockstatscounter_unixclose = 14,
113 isc_sockstatscounter_fdwatchclose = 15,

116 isc_sockstatscounter_udp6bindfail = 17,

120 isc_sockstatscounter_fdwatchbindfail = 21,

123 isc_sockstatscounter_udp6connect = 23,
124 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp4connect = 24,
125 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp6connect = 25,
126 isc_sockstatscounter_unixconnect = 26,
127 isc_sockstatscounter_fdwatchconnect = 27,
128

132 isc_sockstatscounter_tcp6connectfail = 31,
133 isc_sockstatscounter_unixconnectfail = 32,
134 isc_sockstatscounter_fdwatchconnectfail = 33,

138 isc_sockstatscounter_unixaccept = 36,

166 isc_sockstatscounter_rawclose = 59,

171};
172
173/*@{*/
174/*!
175 * _ATTACHED: Internal use only.
176 * _TRUNC: Packet was truncated on receive.
177 * _CTRUNC: Packet control information was truncated. This can
178 * indicate that the packet is not complete, even though
179 * all the data is valid.
180 * _TIMESTAMP: The timestamp member is valid.
181 * _PKTINFO: The pktinfo member is valid.
182 * _MULTICAST: The UDP packet was received via a multicast transmission.
183 * _DSCP: The UDP DSCP value is valid.
184 * _USEMINMTU: Set the per packet IPV6_USE_MIN_MTU flag.
185 */
186typedef enum {
187 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_ATTACHED = 0x10000000U, /* internal */
188 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_TRUNC = 0x00800000U, /* public */
189 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_CTRUNC = 0x00400000U, /* public */
190 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_TIMESTAMP = 0x00200000U, /* public */
191 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_PKTINFO = 0x00100000U, /* public */
192 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_MULTICAST = 0x00080000U, /* public */
193 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_DSCP = 0x00040000U, /* public */
194 ISC_SOCKEVENTATTR_USEMINMTU = 0x00020000U /* public */
195} isc_sockeventattr_t;
196/*@}*/
197
198/***
199 *** Types
200 ***/
201
202struct isc_socketevent {
203 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(isc_socketevent_t);
204 isc_result_t result; /*%< OK, EOF, whatever else */
205 unsigned int minimum; /*%< minimum i/o for event */
206 unsigned int n; /*%< bytes read or written */
207 unsigned int offset; /*%< offset into buffer list */
208 isc_region_t region; /*%< for single-buffer i/o */
209 isc_sockaddr_t address; /*%< source address */
210 isc_time_t timestamp; /*%< timestamp of packet recv */
211 struct in6_pktinfo pktinfo; /*%< ipv6 pktinfo */
212 isc_sockeventattr_t attributes; /*%< see isc_sockeventattr_t
213 enum */
214 isc_eventdestructor_t destroy; /*%< original destructor */
215 unsigned int dscp; /*%< UDP dscp value */
216};
217
218typedef struct isc_socket_newconnev isc_socket_newconnev_t;
219struct isc_socket_newconnev {
220 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(isc_socket_newconnev_t);
221 isc_socket_t * newsocket;
222 isc_result_t result; /*%< OK, EOF, whatever else */
223 isc_sockaddr_t address; /*%< source address */
224};
225
226typedef struct isc_socket_connev isc_socket_connev_t;
227struct isc_socket_connev {
228 ISC_EVENT_COMMON(isc_socket_connev_t);
229 isc_result_t result; /*%< OK, EOF, whatever else */
230};
231
232#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_ANYEVENT (0)
233#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_RECVDONE (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 1)
234#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_SENDDONE (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 2)
235#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_NEWCONN (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 3)
236#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_CONNECT (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 4)
237
238/*
239 * Internal events.
240 */
241#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_INTR (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 256)
242#define ISC_SOCKEVENT_INTW (ISC_EVENTCLASS_SOCKET + 257)
243
244typedef enum {
245 isc_sockettype_udp = 1,
246 isc_sockettype_tcp = 2,
247 isc_sockettype_unix = 3,
248 isc_sockettype_raw = 4,
249 isc_sockettype_fdwatch = 5
250} isc_sockettype_t;
251
252/*@{*/
253/*!
254 * How a socket should be shutdown in isc_socket_shutdown() calls.
255 */
256#define ISC_SOCKSHUT_RECV 0x00000001 /*%< close read side */
257#define ISC_SOCKSHUT_SEND 0x00000002 /*%< close write side */
258#define ISC_SOCKSHUT_ALL 0x00000003 /*%< close them all */
259/*@}*/
260
261/*@{*/
262/*!
263 * What I/O events to cancel in isc_socket_cancel() calls.
264 */
265#define ISC_SOCKCANCEL_RECV 0x00000001 /*%< cancel recv */
266#define ISC_SOCKCANCEL_SEND 0x00000002 /*%< cancel send */
267#define ISC_SOCKCANCEL_ACCEPT 0x00000004 /*%< cancel accept */
268#define ISC_SOCKCANCEL_CONNECT 0x00000008 /*%< cancel connect */
269#define ISC_SOCKCANCEL_ALL 0x0000000f /*%< cancel everything */
270/*@}*/
271
272/*@{*/
273/*!
274 * Flags for isc_socket_send() and isc_socket_recv() calls.
275 */
276#define ISC_SOCKFLAG_IMMEDIATE 0x00000001 /*%< send event only if needed */
277#define ISC_SOCKFLAG_NORETRY 0x00000002 /*%< drop failed UDP sends */
278/*@}*/
279
280/*%
281 * This structure is actually just the common prefix of a socket manager
282 * object implementation's version of an isc_socketmgr_t.
283 * \brief
284 * Direct use of this structure by clients is forbidden. socket implementations
285 * may change the structure. 'magic' must be ISCAPI_SOCKETMGR_MAGIC for any
286 * of the isc_socket_ routines to work. socket implementations must maintain
287 * all socket invariants.
288 * In effect, this definition is used only for non-BIND9 version ("export")
289 * of the library, and the export version does not work for win32. So, to avoid
290 * the definition conflict with win32/socket.c, we enable this definition only
291 * for non-Win32 (i.e. Unix) platforms.
292 */
293#ifndef WIN32
294struct isc_socketmgr {
295 unsigned int impmagic;
296 unsigned int magic;
297};
298#endif
299
300#define ISCAPI_SOCKETMGR_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('A','s','m','g')
301#define ISCAPI_SOCKETMGR_VALID(m) ((m) != NULL && \
302 (m)->magic == ISCAPI_SOCKETMGR_MAGIC)
303
304/*%
305 * This is the common prefix of a socket object. The same note as
306 * that for the socketmgr structure applies.
307 */
308#ifndef WIN32
309struct isc_socket {
310 unsigned int impmagic;
311 unsigned int magic;
312};
313#endif
314
315#define ISCAPI_SOCKET_MAGIC ISC_MAGIC('A','s','c','t')
316#define ISCAPI_SOCKET_VALID(s) ((s) != NULL && \
317 (s)->magic == ISCAPI_SOCKET_MAGIC)
318
319/***
320 *** Socket and Socket Manager Functions
321 ***
322 *** Note: all Ensures conditions apply only if the result is success for
323 *** those functions which return an isc_result.
324 ***/
325
326isc_result_t
327isc_socket_create(isc_socketmgr_t *manager,
328 int pf,
329 isc_sockettype_t type,
330 isc_socket_t **socketp);
331/*%<
332 * Create a new 'type' socket managed by 'manager'.
333 *
334 * Note:
335 *
336 *\li 'pf' is the desired protocol family, e.g. PF_INET or PF_INET6.
337 *
338 * Requires:
339 *
340 *\li 'manager' is a valid manager
341 *
342 *\li 'socketp' is a valid pointer, and *socketp == NULL
343 *
344 * Ensures:
345 *
346 * '*socketp' is attached to the newly created socket
347 *
348 * Returns:
349 *
350 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
351 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
352 *\li #ISC_R_NORESOURCES
353 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
354 */
355
356isc_result_t
357isc_socket_dup(isc_socket_t *sock0, isc_socket_t **socketp);
358/*%<
359 * Duplicate an existing socket, reusing its file descriptor.
360 */
361
362void
363isc_socket_cancel(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_task_t *task,
364 unsigned int how);
365/*%<
366 * Cancel pending I/O of the type specified by "how".
367 *
368 * Note: if "task" is NULL, then the cancel applies to all tasks using the
369 * socket.
370 *
371 * Requires:
372 *
373 * \li "socket" is a valid socket
374 *
375 * \li "task" is NULL or a valid task
376 *
377 * "how" is a bitmask describing the type of cancelation to perform.
378 * The type ISC_SOCKCANCEL_ALL will cancel all pending I/O on this
379 * socket.
380 *
381 * \li ISC_SOCKCANCEL_RECV:
382 * Cancel pending isc_socket_recv() calls.
383 *
384 * \li ISC_SOCKCANCEL_SEND:
385 * Cancel pending isc_socket_send() and isc_socket_sendto() calls.
386 *
387 * \li ISC_SOCKCANCEL_ACCEPT:
388 * Cancel pending isc_socket_accept() calls.
389 *
390 * \li ISC_SOCKCANCEL_CONNECT:
391 * Cancel pending isc_socket_connect() call.
392 */
393
394void
395isc_socket_shutdown(isc_socket_t *sock, unsigned int how);
396/*%<
397 * Shutdown 'socket' according to 'how'.
398 *
399 * Requires:
400 *
401 * \li 'socket' is a valid socket.
402 *
403 * \li 'task' is NULL or is a valid task.
404 *
405 * \li If 'how' is 'ISC_SOCKSHUT_RECV' or 'ISC_SOCKSHUT_ALL' then
406 *
407 * The read queue must be empty.
408 *
409 * No further read requests may be made.
410 *
411 * \li If 'how' is 'ISC_SOCKSHUT_SEND' or 'ISC_SOCKSHUT_ALL' then
412 *
413 * The write queue must be empty.
414 *
415 * No further write requests may be made.
416 */
417
418void
419isc_socket_attach(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_socket_t **socketp);
420/*%<
421 * Attach *socketp to socket.
422 *
423 * Requires:
424 *
425 * \li 'socket' is a valid socket.
426 *
427 * \li 'socketp' points to a NULL socket.
428 *
429 * Ensures:
430 *
431 * \li *socketp is attached to socket.
432 */
433
434void
435isc_socket_detach(isc_socket_t **socketp);
436/*%<
437 * Detach *socketp from its socket.
438 *
439 * Requires:
440 *
441 * \li 'socketp' points to a valid socket.
442 *
443 * \li If '*socketp' is the last reference to the socket,
444 * then:
445 *
446 * There must be no pending I/O requests.
447 *
448 * Ensures:
449 *
450 * \li *socketp is NULL.
451 *
452 * \li If '*socketp' is the last reference to the socket,
453 * then:
454 *
455 * The socket will be shutdown (both reading and writing)
456 * for all tasks.
457 *
458 * All resources used by the socket have been freed
459 */
460
461isc_result_t
462isc_socket_open(isc_socket_t *sock);
463/*%<
464 * Open a new socket file descriptor of the given socket structure. It simply
465 * opens a new descriptor; all of the other parameters including the socket
466 * type are inherited from the existing socket. This function is provided to
467 * avoid overhead of destroying and creating sockets when many short-lived
468 * sockets are frequently opened and closed. When the efficiency is not an
469 * issue, it should be safer to detach the unused socket and re-create a new
470 * one. This optimization may not be available for some systems, in which
471 * case this function will return ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED and must not be used.
472 *
473 * Requires:
474 *
475 * \li there must be no other reference to this socket.
476 *
477 * \li 'socket' is a valid and previously closed by isc_socket_close()
478 *
479 * Returns:
480 * Same as isc_socket_create().
481 * \li ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED
482 */
483
484isc_result_t
485isc_socket_close(isc_socket_t *sock);
486/*%<
487 * Close a socket file descriptor of the given socket structure. This function
488 * is provided as an alternative to destroying an unused socket when overhead
489 * destroying/re-creating sockets can be significant, and is expected to be
490 * used with isc_socket_open(). This optimization may not be available for some
491 * systems, in which case this function will return ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED and
492 * must not be used.
493 *
494 * Requires:
495 *
496 * \li The socket must have a valid descriptor.
497 *
498 * \li There must be no other reference to this socket.
499 *
500 * \li There must be no pending I/O requests.
501 *
502 * Returns:
503 * \li #ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED
504 */
505
506isc_result_t
507isc_socket_bind(isc_socket_t *sock, const isc_sockaddr_t *addressp,
508 isc_socket_options_t options);
509/*%<
510 * Bind 'socket' to '*addressp'.
511 *
512 * Requires:
513 *
514 * \li 'socket' is a valid socket
515 *
516 * \li 'addressp' points to a valid isc_sockaddr.
517 *
518 * Returns:
519 *
520 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
521 * \li ISC_R_NOPERM
522 * \li ISC_R_ADDRNOTAVAIL
523 * \li ISC_R_ADDRINUSE
524 * \li ISC_R_BOUND
525 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
526 */
527
528isc_result_t
529isc_socket_filter(isc_socket_t *sock, const char *filter);
530/*%<
531 * Inform the kernel that it should perform accept filtering.
532 * If filter is NULL the current filter will be removed.:w
533 */
534
535isc_result_t
536isc_socket_listen(isc_socket_t *sock, unsigned int backlog);
537/*%<
538 * Set listen mode on the socket. After this call, the only function that
539 * can be used (other than attach and detach) is isc_socket_accept().
540 *
541 * Notes:
542 *
543 * \li 'backlog' is as in the UNIX system call listen() and may be
544 * ignored by non-UNIX implementations.
545 *
546 * \li If 'backlog' is zero, a reasonable system default is used, usually
547 * SOMAXCONN.
548 *
549 * Requires:
550 *
551 * \li 'socket' is a valid, bound TCP socket or a valid, bound UNIX socket.
552 *
553 * Returns:
554 *
555 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
556 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
557 */
558
559isc_result_t
560isc_socket_accept(isc_socket_t *sock,
561 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg);
562/*%<
563 * Queue accept event. When a new connection is received, the task will
564 * get an ISC_SOCKEVENT_NEWCONN event with the sender set to the listen
565 * socket. The new socket structure is sent inside the isc_socket_newconnev_t
566 * event type, and is attached to the task 'task'.
567 *
568 * REQUIRES:
569 * \li 'socket' is a valid TCP socket that isc_socket_listen() was called
570 * on.
571 *
572 * \li 'task' is a valid task
573 *
574 * \li 'action' is a valid action
575 *
576 * RETURNS:
577 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
578 * \li ISC_R_NOMEMORY
579 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
580 */
581
582isc_result_t
583isc_socket_connect(isc_socket_t *sock, const isc_sockaddr_t *addressp,
584 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action,
585 void *arg);
586/*%<
587 * Connect 'socket' to peer with address *saddr. When the connection
588 * succeeds, or when an error occurs, a CONNECT event with action 'action'
589 * and arg 'arg' will be posted to the event queue for 'task'.
590 *
591 * Requires:
592 *
593 * \li 'socket' is a valid TCP socket
594 *
595 * \li 'addressp' points to a valid isc_sockaddr
596 *
597 * \li 'task' is a valid task
598 *
599 * \li 'action' is a valid action
600 *
601 * Returns:
602 *
603 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
604 * \li ISC_R_NOMEMORY
605 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
606 *
607 * Posted event's result code:
608 *
609 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
610 * \li ISC_R_TIMEDOUT
611 * \li ISC_R_CONNREFUSED
612 * \li ISC_R_NETUNREACH
613 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
614 */
615
616isc_result_t
617isc_socket_getpeername(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_sockaddr_t *addressp);
618/*%<
619 * Get the name of the peer connected to 'socket'.
620 *
621 * Requires:
622 *
623 * \li 'socket' is a valid TCP socket.
624 *
625 * Returns:
626 *
627 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
628 * \li ISC_R_TOOSMALL
629 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
630 */
631
632isc_result_t
633isc_socket_getsockname(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_sockaddr_t *addressp);
634/*%<
635 * Get the name of 'socket'.
636 *
637 * Requires:
638 *
639 * \li 'socket' is a valid socket.
640 *
641 * Returns:
642 *
643 * \li ISC_R_SUCCESS
644 * \li ISC_R_TOOSMALL
645 * \li ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
646 */
647
648/*@{*/
649isc_result_t
650isc_socket_recv(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_region_t *region,
651 unsigned int minimum,
652 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg);
653
654isc_result_t
655isc_socket_recv2(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_region_t *region,
656 unsigned int minimum, isc_task_t *task,
657 isc_socketevent_t *event, unsigned int flags);
658
659/*!
660 * Receive from 'socket', storing the results in region.
661 *
662 * Notes:
663 *
664 *\li Let 'length' refer to the length of 'region' or to the sum of all
665 * available regions in the list of buffers '*buflist'.
666 *
667 *\li If 'minimum' is non-zero and at least that many bytes are read,
668 * the completion event will be posted to the task 'task.' If minimum
669 * is zero, the exact number of bytes requested in the region must
670 * be read for an event to be posted. This only makes sense for TCP
671 * connections, and is always set to 1 byte for UDP.
672 *
673 *\li The read will complete when the desired number of bytes have been
674 * read, if end-of-input occurs, or if an error occurs. A read done
675 * event with the given 'action' and 'arg' will be posted to the
676 * event queue of 'task'.
677 *
678 *\li The caller may not modify 'region', the buffers which are passed
679 * into this function, or any data they refer to until the completion
680 * event is received.
681 *
682 *\li For isc_socket_recv2():
683 * 'event' is not NULL, and the non-socket specific fields are
684 * expected to be initialized.
685 *
686 *\li For isc_socket_recv2():
687 * The only defined value for 'flags' is ISC_SOCKFLAG_IMMEDIATE. If
688 * set and the operation completes, the return value will be
689 * ISC_R_SUCCESS and the event will be filled in and not sent. If the
690 * operation does not complete, the return value will be
691 * ISC_R_INPROGRESS and the event will be sent when the operation
692 * completes.
693 *
694 * Requires:
695 *
696 *\li 'socket' is a valid, bound socket.
697 *
698 *\li For isc_socket_recv():
699 * 'region' is a valid region
700 *
701 *\li For isc_socket_recvv():
702 * 'buflist' is non-NULL, and '*buflist' contain at least one buffer.
703 *
704 *\li 'task' is a valid task
705 *
706 *\li For isc_socket_recv() and isc_socket_recvv():
707 * action != NULL and is a valid action
708 *
709 *\li For isc_socket_recv2():
710 * event != NULL
711 *
712 * Returns:
713 *
714 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
715 *\li #ISC_R_INPROGRESS
716 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
717 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
718 *
719 * Event results:
720 *
721 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
722 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
723 *\li XXX needs other net-type errors
724 */
725/*@}*/
726
727/*@{*/
728isc_result_t
729isc_socket_send(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_region_t *region,
730 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg);
731isc_result_t
732isc_socket_sendto(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_region_t *region,
733 isc_task_t *task, isc_taskaction_t action, void *arg,
734 const isc_sockaddr_t *address, struct in6_pktinfo *pktinfo);
735isc_result_t
736isc_socket_sendto2(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_region_t *region,
737 isc_task_t *task,
738 const isc_sockaddr_t *address, struct in6_pktinfo *pktinfo,
739 isc_socketevent_t *event, unsigned int flags);
740
741/*!
742 * Send the contents of 'region' to the socket's peer.
743 *
744 * Notes:
745 *
746 *\li Shutting down the requestor's task *may* result in any
747 * still pending writes being dropped or completed, depending on the
748 * underlying OS implementation.
749 *
750 *\li If 'action' is NULL, then no completion event will be posted.
751 *
752 *\li The caller may not modify 'region', the buffers which are passed
753 * into this function, or any data they refer to until the completion
754 * event is received.
755 *
756 *\li For isc_socket_sendto2():
757 * 'event' is not NULL, and the non-socket specific fields are
758 * expected to be initialized.
759 *
760 *\li For isc_socket_sendto2():
761 * The only defined values for 'flags' are ISC_SOCKFLAG_IMMEDIATE
762 * and ISC_SOCKFLAG_NORETRY.
763 *
764 *\li If ISC_SOCKFLAG_IMMEDIATE is set and the operation completes, the
765 * return value will be ISC_R_SUCCESS and the event will be filled
766 * in and not sent. If the operation does not complete, the return
767 * value will be ISC_R_INPROGRESS and the event will be sent when
768 * the operation completes.
769 *
770 *\li ISC_SOCKFLAG_NORETRY can only be set for UDP sockets. If set
771 * and the send operation fails due to a transient error, the send
772 * will not be retried and the error will be indicated in the event.
773 * Using this option along with ISC_SOCKFLAG_IMMEDIATE allows the caller
774 * to specify a region that is allocated on the stack.
775 *
776 * Requires:
777 *
778 *\li 'socket' is a valid, bound socket.
779 *
780 *\li For isc_socket_send():
781 * 'region' is a valid region
782 *
783 *\li For isc_socket_sendv() and isc_socket_sendtov():
784 * 'buflist' is non-NULL, and '*buflist' contain at least one buffer.
785 *
786 *\li 'task' is a valid task
787 *
788 *\li For isc_socket_sendv(), isc_socket_sendtov(), isc_socket_send(), and
789 * isc_socket_sendto():
790 * action == NULL or is a valid action
791 *
792 *\li For isc_socket_sendto2():
793 * event != NULL
794 *
795 * Returns:
796 *
797 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
798 *\li #ISC_R_INPROGRESS
799 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
800 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
801 *
802 * Event results:
803 *
804 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
805 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
806 *\li XXX needs other net-type errors
807 */
808/*@}*/
809
810isc_result_t
811isc_socketmgr_createinctx(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_appctx_t *actx,
812 isc_socketmgr_t **managerp);
813
814isc_result_t
815isc_socketmgr_create(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_socketmgr_t **managerp);
816
817isc_result_t
818isc_socketmgr_create2(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_socketmgr_t **managerp,
819 unsigned int maxsocks, int nthreads);
820/*%<
821 * Create a socket manager. If "maxsocks" is non-zero, it specifies the
822 * maximum number of sockets that the created manager should handle.
823 * isc_socketmgr_create() is equivalent of isc_socketmgr_create2() with
824 * "maxsocks" being zero.
825 * isc_socketmgr_createinctx() also associates the new manager with the
826 * specified application context.
827 *
828 * Notes:
829 *
830 *\li All memory will be allocated in memory context 'mctx'.
831 *
832 * Requires:
833 *
834 *\li 'mctx' is a valid memory context.
835 *
836 *\li 'managerp' points to a NULL isc_socketmgr_t.
837 *
838 *\li 'actx' is a valid application context (for createinctx()).
839 *
840 * Ensures:
841 *
842 *\li '*managerp' is a valid isc_socketmgr_t.
843 *
844 * Returns:
845 *
846 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
847 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
848 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
849 *\li #ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED
850 */
851
852isc_result_t
853isc_socketmgr_getmaxsockets(isc_socketmgr_t *manager, unsigned int *nsockp);
854/*%<
855 * Returns in "*nsockp" the maximum number of sockets this manager may open.
856 *
857 * Requires:
858 *
859 *\li '*manager' is a valid isc_socketmgr_t.
860 *\li 'nsockp' is not NULL.
861 *
862 * Returns:
863 *
864 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
865 *\li #ISC_R_NOTIMPLEMENTED
866 */
867
868void
869isc_socketmgr_setstats(isc_socketmgr_t *manager, isc_stats_t *stats);
870/*%<
871 * Set a general socket statistics counter set 'stats' for 'manager'.
872 *
873 * Requires:
874 * \li 'manager' is valid, hasn't opened any socket, and doesn't have
875 * stats already set.
876 *
877 *\li stats is a valid statistics supporting socket statistics counters
878 * (see above).
879 */
880
881void
882isc_socketmgr_destroy(isc_socketmgr_t **managerp);
883/*%<
884 * Destroy a socket manager.
885 *
886 * Notes:
887 *
888 *\li This routine blocks until there are no sockets left in the manager,
889 * so if the caller holds any socket references using the manager, it
890 * must detach them before calling isc_socketmgr_destroy() or it will
891 * block forever.
892 *
893 * Requires:
894 *
895 *\li '*managerp' is a valid isc_socketmgr_t.
896 *
897 *\li All sockets managed by this manager are fully detached.
898 *
899 * Ensures:
900 *
901 *\li *managerp == NULL
902 *
903 *\li All resources used by the manager have been freed.
904 */
905
906isc_sockettype_t
907isc_socket_gettype(isc_socket_t *sock);
908/*%<
909 * Returns the socket type for "sock."
910 *
911 * Requires:
912 *
913 *\li "sock" is a valid socket.
914 */
915
916/*@{*/
917void
918isc_socket_ipv6only(isc_socket_t *sock, bool yes);
919/*%<
920 * If the socket is an IPv6 socket set/clear the IPV6_IPV6ONLY socket
921 * option if the host OS supports this option.
922 *
923 * Requires:
924 *\li 'sock' is a valid socket.
925 */
926/*@}*/
927
928void
929isc_socket_dscp(isc_socket_t *sock, isc_dscp_t dscp);
930/*%<
931 * Sets the Differentiated Services Code Point (DSCP) field for packets
932 * transmitted on this socket. If 'dscp' is -1, return immediately.
933 *
934 * Requires:
935 *\li 'sock' is a valid socket.
936 */
937
938isc_socketevent_t *
939isc_socket_socketevent(isc_mem_t *mctx, void *sender,
940 isc_eventtype_t eventtype, isc_taskaction_t action,
941 void *arg);
942/*%<
943 * Get a isc_socketevent_t to be used with isc_socket_sendto2(), etc.
944 */
945
946void
947isc_socket_cleanunix(const isc_sockaddr_t *addr, bool active);
948
949/*%<
950 * Cleanup UNIX domain sockets in the file-system. If 'active' is true
951 * then just unlink the socket. If 'active' is false try to determine
952 * if there is a listener of the socket or not. If no listener is found
953 * then unlink socket.
954 *
955 * Prior to unlinking the path is tested to see if it a socket.
956 *
957 * Note: there are a number of race conditions which cannot be avoided
958 * both in the filesystem and any application using UNIX domain
959 * sockets (e.g. socket is tested between bind() and listen(),
960 * the socket is deleted and replaced in the file-system between
961 * stat() and unlink()).
962 */
963
964isc_result_t
965isc_socket_permunix(const isc_sockaddr_t *sockaddr, uint32_t perm,
966 uint32_t owner, uint32_t group);
967/*%<
968 * Set ownership and file permissions on the UNIX domain socket.
969 *
970 * Note: On Solaris this secures the directory containing
971 * the socket as Solaris do not honour the filesystem
972 * permissions on the socket.
973 *
974 * Requires:
975 * \li 'sockaddr' to be a valid UNIX domain sockaddr.
976 *
977 * Returns:
978 * \li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
979 * \li #ISC_R_FAILURE
980 */
981
982void isc_socket_setname(isc_socket_t *socket, const char *name, void *tag);
983/*%<
984 * Set the name and optional tag for a socket. This allows tracking of the
985 * owner or purpose for this socket, and is useful for tracing and statistics
986 * reporting.
987 */
988
989const char *isc_socket_getname(isc_socket_t *socket);
990/*%<
991 * Get the name associated with a socket, if any.
992 */
993
994void *isc_socket_gettag(isc_socket_t *socket);
995/*%<
996 * Get the tag associated with a socket, if any.
997 */
998
999int isc_socket_getfd(isc_socket_t *socket);
1000/*%<
1001 * Get the file descriptor associated with a socket
1002 */
1003
1004void
1005isc_socketmgr_setreserved(isc_socketmgr_t *mgr, uint32_t);
1006/*%<
1007 * Temporary. For use by named only.
1008 */
1009
1010void
1011isc_socketmgr_maxudp(isc_socketmgr_t *mgr, int maxudp);
1012/*%<
1013 * Test interface. Drop UDP packet > 'maxudp'.
1014 */
1015

1017isc_socket_hasreuseport(void);

1020 */

1038/*%<
1039 * See isc_socketmgr_create() above.
1040 */
1041typedef isc_result_t
1042(*isc_socketmgrcreatefunc_t)(isc_mem_t *mctx, isc_socketmgr_t **managerp);
1043/*!
1044 * Flags for fdwatchcreate.
1045 */
1046#define ISC_SOCKFDWATCH_READ 0x00000001 /*%< watch for readable */
1047#define ISC_SOCKFDWATCH_WRITE 0x00000002 /*%< watch for writable */
1048/*@}*/
1049
1050isc_result_t
1051isc_socket_fdwatchcreate(isc_socketmgr_t *manager,
1052 int fd,
1053 int flags,
1054 isc_sockfdwatch_t callback,
1055 void *cbarg,
1056 isc_task_t *task,
1057 isc_socket_t **socketp);
1058/*%<
1059 * Create a new file descriptor watch socket managed by 'manager'.
1060 *
1061 * Note:
1062 *
1063 *\li 'fd' is the already-opened file descriptor (must be less
1064 * than maxsockets).
1065 *\li This function is not available on Windows.
1066 *\li The callback function is called "in-line" - this means the function
1067 * needs to return as fast as possible, as all other I/O will be suspended
1068 * until the callback completes.
1069 *
1070 * Requires:
1071 *
1072 *\li 'manager' is a valid manager
1073 *
1074 *\li 'socketp' is a valid pointer, and *socketp == NULL
1075 *
1076 *\li 'fd' be opened.
1077 *
1078 * Ensures:
1079 *
1080 * '*socketp' is attached to the newly created fdwatch socket
1081 *
1082 * Returns:
1083 *
1084 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
1085 *\li #ISC_R_NOMEMORY
1086 *\li #ISC_R_NORESOURCES
1087 *\li #ISC_R_UNEXPECTED
1088 *\li #ISC_R_RANGE
1089 */
1090
1091isc_result_t
1092isc_socket_fdwatchpoke(isc_socket_t *sock,
1093 int flags);
1094/*%<
1095 * Poke a file descriptor watch socket informing the manager that it
1096 * should restart watching the socket
1097 *
1098 * Note:
1099 *
1100 *\li 'sock' is the socket returned by isc_socket_fdwatchcreate
1101 *
1102 *\li 'flags' indicates what the manager should watch for on the socket
1103 * in addition to what it may already be watching. It can be one or
1104 * both of ISC_SOCKFDWATCH_READ and ISC_SOCKFDWATCH_WRITE. To
1105 * temporarily disable watching on a socket the value indicating
1106 * no more data should be returned from the call back routine.
1107 *
1108 *\li This function is not available on Windows.
1109 *
1110 * Requires:
1111 *
1112 *\li 'sock' is a valid isc socket
1113 *
1114 *
1115 * Returns:
1116 *
1117 *\li #ISC_R_SUCCESS
1118 */
1119
1120ISC_LANG_ENDDECLS
